summary: The brilliance of the Captain Marvel script
title: The brilliance of the Captain Marvel script
body:
For starters, I enjoyed Captain Marvel thoroughly. It was fun, charming, interestingly told, and with eye-catching action. In a further rewatch what I enjoyed most was the connecting dialog and the oh-so satisfying setups.

Spoilers. Here. Now.

Let’s start of course with the final punchline: The “Protector” Initiative. We now know Carol Danvers is the original “Avenger”, but the setup is early on as we see Maria Rambeau’s name on the side of her fighter jet: Captain Maria “Photon” Rambeau. We get distracted by the “Captain” (like in the movie’s title!) and the “Photon” (Monica in da house!), but we should be putting more weight in figuring out Carol’s nickname by that point. Great setup.

The music is fantastically used as a mood changer on a dime. From the very first Salt and Peppa beat when the security guard opens the car window, to Garbage coming on to exemplify that Vers has assimilated into her mission, setting up the connecting pop music does a lot of the heavy lifting. The best examples of instant mood creation comes in the third act when Nirvana kicks in and we’re inside Supreme Intelligence and better yet is when No Doubt defines the tone of the final battle: she’s so powerful there are no stakes anymore, we’re here to have some fun.

One knows that Fury has to lose the eye at some point, but by the end one is so invested in this group’s adventure that it becomes a moot point… until Goose happens., and Thalos goes “Oh, no”, which in itself is set up when Fury asks: “Is this turbulence normal?”, and Thalos nods “no”. Let alone the red herring of the eye injury during the car crash.

Close to the end, Carol ignites Yon-Rogg’s vessel with her new found powers. That ability is set up when Yon-Rogg throws her against a collider on the space lab and she sparks the big machine on.

My favorite setup is her name: Vers. We hardly connect her alien name to her human name. Halfway through the movie in the box of memories at Maria’s house we see the pierced dogtag that reads “Carol Dan” and we still don’t connect the dots. It’s until Yon.Rogg in an act of possession grabs the piece of the dogtag and defines her as Vers. Again, a great reveal that links to a previous scene.

This script is so rich and well thought out. Glad to see the work of this ample team of writers recognized.

summary: CarolMaria is the MCU version of CarolJess
body:
CarolMaria is the MCU version of CarolJess

Wow, it took me so long to form a connection. Jessica Drew in the comics is a very integral and important relationship and part of Carol’s life and story. Jess was there to help Carol recover her memories the first time she lost them to Rouge and continues to be her #1 supporter and best friend. Jess also has a comic arc where she becomes a single mother in her stand alone comic issues. Carol was there for her after Secret Invasion and continues to support her. They are each other’s support system and best friend, to the point where it is totally plausible for them to fall into a relationship, aka CarolJess. They have not introduced Spider-Woman to the MCU, and it would be awkward in the setting and story timeline Captain Marvel takes place in.

They also needed to address Monica Rambeau as well, since she carried the title before and has similar powers.

So what do they do? It would be better if Monica was an adult in the present time, that would mean she would be a child when Captain Marvel takes place. And they transfer that deep relationship and support Carol has with Jess over to Monica’s mother, Maria. Maria is a single mother as well, who Carol helps support; and they both have each other’s backs as pilots and best friends. Maria helps Carol with her amnesia like Jess does, albeit in a different way. So unless they introduce Jessica Drew later on, this is what got formulated in my brain. Jess and Carol’s history and relationship are too important to not be addressed at all in the MCU when it is sooo important in the comics.

summary:
Brie Larson: TIME 100 Most Influential People Of 2019
BRIE LARSON
By Tessa Thompson
Actress and director Brie Larson
Amanda...
body:
Brie Larson: TIME 100 Most Influential People Of 2019


BRIE LARSON

By Tessa Thompson

Actress and director Brie Larson

Amanda Demme—Art Partner

Brie Larson is a warrior on- and offscreen. When she’s not shattering records and stereotypes as Captain Marvel in Marvel Studios’ first female-led superhero movie—which has made more than $1 billion at the global box office—she’s fighting fiercely for gender equality, inclusivity and an end to sexual harassment in the workplace.

For Brie, it just comes naturally. Her activism is an extension of who she is. She sits at a table and wants to make sure everyone has access to it. She is constantly investigating how to be a better ally. The first time I met her, she was taking a breather outside of an annual adult prom; the next time, she was hosting a conversation (complete with graphs and a PowerPoint presentation) about the lack of representation in film. She has a huge capacity for both joy and serious work.

Brie is primed to be one of Marvel’s next big leaders at a time when women are breaking ceilings in all spaces. She is in a position to make real systemic change in Hollywood. I’m elated to see someone so pure of intention wield that power.

Thompson is an actor who stars alongside Larson in the upcoming movie Avengers: Endgame



We only stan one queen. Brianne Sidonie Desaulniers aka Brie Larson👑👑👑👑🔥🔥🔥❤️😍

For Brie, it just comes naturally. Her activism is an extension of who she is. She sits at a table and wants to make sure everyone has access to it. She is constantly investigating how to be a better ally. The first time I met her, she was taking a breather outside of an annual adult prom; the next time, she was hosting a conversation (complete with graphs and a PowerPoint presentation) about the lack of representation in film. She has a huge capacity for both joy and serious work.

Brie is primed to be one of Marvel’s next big leaders at a time when women are breaking ceilings in all spaces. She is in a position to make real systemic change in Hollywood. I’m elated to see someone so pure of intention wield that power.

Thompson is an actor who stars alongside Larson in the upcoming movie Avengers: Endgame



We only stan one queen. Brianne Sidonie Desaulniers aka Brie Larson👑👑👑👑🔥🔥🔥❤️😍

summary: After watching Captain Marvel, I’m starting a film retrospective of Anna Boden & Ryan Fleck movies. I’ve now seen Mississippi...
caption:
After watching Captain Marvel, I’m starting a film retrospective of Anna Boden & Ryan Fleck movies.

I’ve now seen Mississippi Grind to start things off and there are fascinating similarities with Captain Marvel beyond starring Ben Mendelsohn.

Spoilers. Here. Now.

First off it’s nice to see with which other MCU actors Boden & Fleck have worked with before. In Grind there is Alfre Woodard who spends the same amount of screen-time as she does in Civil War. Ryan Reynolds can only feel as a fellow picturemaker. Grind is done sort of guerrilla style and the journey before Deadpool’s production was as guerrilla as you can get within the studio system. One of Anthony Mackie’s early roles was in Half-Nelson, maybe the always enthusiastic Mackie was one of the first to welcome Anna and Ryan to the MCU.

But let’s get into the shared themes and beats bethween Mississippi Grind and Captain Marvel. For starters, both are road trip movies. One of the best parts of CM is how many places Vers/Carol travels to and the journey is as propulsive as her personality both as a fighter pilot and as part of Starforce. The guys in Grind have to travel from Iowa to New Orleans not always sure of the purpose, or even more so, the sense of the effort.

A strong theme on both films is the sense of self. Do they know who they really are? Skrulls are a literal representation of the instability of who one is, but Carol is framed in a different light. She knows what her personality and moral compass are but she can’t be sure that her actions support that. In Grind it’s the opposite, both Gerry and Curtis like to gamble, that’s a fact, and they do for very different reasons. And they’re good to each other and for one and other, but are they good people, or not? That is what we’re here to find out and every chapter of the trip we think we have them figured ou, but we never entirely do, to the very last shot.

The unreliable company seems to be present in both stories. Vers seems too confident and abrupt in how she judges people, and that has to crack. Gerry and Curtis think they know know each other enough to travel together, they aknowledge each other’s dark side as acceptable risk. They’ll be (and us) surprised at every opportunity. Does Gerry think that he’s helping Curtis settle down? Is smiley/self-loathing Curtis think he’s helping Gerry by tricking him out of the horse race winnings?

The pinnacle of mirrored themes to me comes once again with Mendelsohn’s character at the center. In Captain Marvel, the directors keep showing us that Thalos is softer than we first believe when he zaps and captures Carol. He’s funny while messing with her memories, he’s heartfelt when he meets up with his dead comrade, and he’s cooperative when he meets up with the crew at Maria’s house. And yet, when we see that Mar-Vell’s space lab is occupied and Thalos begins what appears to be a battle cry, we swing back to distrusting him, “It’s a trap!”, but once again our fears are unfounded. It’s not a trap, we now trust the kindness of strangers. Meanwhile in Grind, Gerry who can’t seem to enjoy anything good that comes his way, either it being money or even a friend, seems to destroy his last relationship by leaving Curtis behind only to reaffirm that he does have at some level an interest in having his new acquaintance live a happier, more fulfilling life.

blog.name: silveragelovechild
blog.title: SILVER AGE LOVE CHILD
blog.description: The Silver Age was as simpler era with comics that fueled my imagination. I'll share favorite graphic art, pop culture & sci-fi.

summary:
HEROES CALL MARVEL # 8 - MARVELMAN
Marvelman was created by Mick Anglo and first appeared in “Marvelman” #25 (Feb. 1954). 
While...
body:
HEROES CALL MARVEL # 8 - MARVELMAN

Marvelman was created by Mick Anglo and first appeared in “Marvelman” #25 (Feb. 1954).

While the legal battle between Fawcett Comics and DC Comics was going on in the USA, L. Miller & Son, Ltd had been republished B&W issues of the Captain Marvel stories. But when Fawcett decided to settle out of court with DC, Miller & Son were in a bind - new issues of their reprint would soon end. Sales were strong enough that they commissioned comic package Mick Anglo to come up with a replacement.

Anglo came up with a very thinly revised Captain Marvel with the original name Marvelman. Marvelman’s alter-ego was Micky Moran and when he said KIMOTA (Atomic backwards) he transformed into a costumed hero. While Captain Marvel had black hair and wore a red costume, Marvelman had blonde hair and a blue costume. Captain Marvel’s arch rival was scientist Dr. Sivana and Marvelman fought Dr. Gargunza.

Marvelman comic picked up the numbering of the former Captain Marvel comic and first appeared in Marvelman #25 (Feb. 1954). It continued for 346 issues (most weekly). It’s important to note that Mick Angelo occasionally included “© Mick Anglo” in some issues.
